snippet: After the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban won the award, architecture’s highest honor, the clamor for a piece of the prize became palpable at his two projects in Manhattan.
abstract: Appraisal column; in age of high-flying real estate, brand-name architecture and globe-trotting wealth, identity of designers has taken on ever-increasing value to ensure that a project’s multimillion-dollar homes stand out; Japanese architect Shigeru Ban's only completed project in New York, three-bedroom condominium inside the Metal Shutter Houses in West Chelsea, went to top of broker lists after he won the Pritzker Prize.
lead_paragraph: After the Japanese architect Shigeru Ban won the award, architecture’s highest honor, the clamor for a piece of the prize became palpable at his two projects in Manhattan.

headline.main: Interest in a Property Grows With One Key Addition: An Architecture Prize
headline.print_headline: Interest in a Property Grows With One Key Addition: An Architecture Prize
